author: skeleman547
body:
Ok, I'm going to tag my thoughts about AMD in the datacenter as a system admin/engineer in a medium size company with massive growth goals over the next 5 years. 

We absolutely aren't looking at ARM chips for datacenter work, and their lack of compatibility with legacy line of business software is a drawback for even end-user work. (We're using entirely x64 traditional architecture in our fleet right now.) 

As Hyperconverged network/virtualization/storage/compute infrastructure continues to grow in the datacenter world, AMD will need to compete with non-traditional companies in this sector like Cisco, but I believe the cost of Cisco Hyperconverged infrastructure limits their appeal to many SMB size companies. 

Lastly, I see regular advertisements from HPE (our current vendor) showcasing the benefits of AMD processors in the datacenter, but I see little from Dell EMC and some other vendors we are working with. If AMD can secure the kind of exposure they are getting from HPE with other vendors and increase their name recognition and reputation in the Datacenter market, thats going to be a massive boost to sales. 

\*Disclosure\* I own AMD stock, my personal machine has an AMD processor, and I would do unspeakable acts for a 6000 series graphics card. Do your own research, and I am not a financial advisor. 

Tl;Dr: AMD make expensive machines go brrrrrrrr, I like the stock, etc.

author: MrWFL
body:
Vodafone needs companies like Nokia to help them get their 5G. Nokia is the only one who can do 5G antennas, 5g coordinator software, 5g routers, low latency optical routers, router managenent software, 5g consumer access point (basically all the stuff you would to provide 5g technology to consumers)

If you don't use Nokia, you might, as a 5g service provider, need qualcomm for your consumer access points, ericsson as antennas and antenna coordinator software, and cisco for your low latency optical routers)

&#x200B;

Vodaphone would be a nokia client, not a competitor.

author: 1foxyboi
body: CSCO still waiting on that time in the market to break its ath from 1999

author: irresponsible_owl
body:
I'm over twice your age and there are many companies you could have said that about in the past.

As recently as 2004, GE was the biggest company in the world and nobody thought it was going anywhere. During the dotcom bubble, nobody thought Cisco could ever fail. 

Those companies haven't exactly failed, but they have seriously underperformed the market and you would have lost a ton of money if they were your only investment when they were at the top.

Companies at the top don't stay there for long.

author: sharist_DIY_bio
body: Well, just got a call from some of my friends back home in SF, Cisco and Alphabet folks, who SHOCKING! were not at the office, but rather on Ocean Beach, missing me. So gosh. That's cool. What is not cool, lol, is that they were in serious danger from some Kite flyers who had elaborate kites they could not control and felt threatened, by you guessed it: kites! LOL. And all they could think of was to call me and say wish you were here to open a can of whoopass and get those folks in line. lol. I like to think my pain in the ass status is temporary, but apparently, it has been going on for decades. lol. Safety first. Not a bad thing to be remembered for. But really? Ocean Beach get together? Kite fucks? Live to serve, serve to learn. You at r/Spacs, are apparently not the first crew I have annoyed. Stay sane. Got your back, if I can. Call me if some random fucks fly elaborate kites they cannot control. Just to be friends. lol. Always take the high road, my friends. Glad to be thought of as fiercely defending my peeps. That was so random. You guys natter and matter... have a good day. Elsewhere, my shit really tanked today, again. Warrant clown, not leaving.

author: Ahrideva
body:
That's what worries me most -- that it's been at all time highs for so long. Buying at a markup without considering fundamental analysis counts as yoloing in my book. It doesn't matter that the company is great if you buy it too dearly.

In the 2000 crash some large cap tech companies were massively overbought and they crashed badly, even though they were great companies. Take a look at Cisco.

author: lattiboy
body:
Oracle and Cisco are basically industrials right now. 

I’m doing Cisco because I’m in IT and their prices are absurd (no sales, ever) and the current wait time for some types of equipment is very long. 

Oracle is in a similar boat with IT upgrades. They can charge literally anything they want. Once you’re in; you’re absolutely stuck with them and business are having to do huge it upgrades for security and increased scope of IT.

author: pittiedad
body: Most people see Nokia and think cell phones. When Nokia purchased Alcatel-Lucent, they inherited one of the most popular portfolios of service provider grade routers. I can state with absolute certainty that the majority of the globes internet traffic passes through at least one 7750 or 7950. It has been interesting to see Cisco and Juniper devices slowly replaced with Nokia devices by some of the largest global service providers. Knowing all this, I agree they are undervalued.

author: DayoftheDead
body: As someone that doesn’t work in tech..... I have to ask how you feel about Cisco.

author: Investing8675309
body: Haha, they’re on my hit list too, just not to the level IBM and Oracle are. The CSPs hate them just because they overcharge for their proprietary networking gear (back end, not talking like office equipment) and have patents up to wazoo on them. I won’t touch them either but am outside of my expertise when speaking about their consumer products. They’re similar to Oracle in that a lot of the industry hates using them but they’re just really hard to move away from. A lot of networking has gone open source in an effort to get away from Cisco though this has had mixed results. Again though, I only know one aspect of their business relatively well so can’t comment on everything but it is enough that I won’t buy this stock. They’re also on the Acquirers Multiple as like the number two or three holding so great value.

author: Calichurner
body:
I don’t get the macro argument at all. If a company grow earnings, the share prices will always follow. SPACs are early stage VC type of investments and retail get to invest in the floor vs chasing IPO at the top and end up holding the bags.

Democrats are throwing trillions into the system, vaccination gaining steam, Fed’s low interest policy until late 2022/early 2023 all bode well for economic growth. Growth companies will do really well in that scenario. Of course, the cruises, the hospitality sector and airlines will do well because they are returning to normalcy. But, I wouldn’t count out innovative growth companies. I would rather invest in EVs, eVTols, etc vs traditional oil companies. 

If you looked at history, they had wars, recessions but companies like MSFT, DELL, CSCO, etc became multi-baggers and made people wealthy. As Peter Lynch said “a stock market decline is as routine as a January blizzard in Colorado.” He also said “ignore the pundits and economists, act like a dumb mule and you’ll make money in the market.”

SPAC Tulip mania may be over, but disruptive early stage companies will make us rich. Cheers!

author: dr3amboy3657
body:
I get what you are saying but at some point you have to sell and enjoy your profits.  Some blue chips stay down/sideways for a long ass time, are you willing to ride them sideways for 10+ years?  And sometimes blue chips become dead money.

Some recent examples: KO, MO, MSFT (before 2017), CSCO, any OIL stocks the last 10 years.

author: ilai_reddead
body: Here's my problem with tesla I have no doubt they will be a large car company but they are so grossly overpriced that it is ridiculous. Even if they smash all expect it won't matter because the market has priced in everything. Tesla is a large car, energy, software and God knows what else when in some of those categories they getimg beat by other manufacturers, so really it's just so much speculation. I have no doubt tesla will be successful but buying now is paying for perfection and more and I'm really not Into that. Also the argument that tesla is like apple or Amazon back in 2000 is ridiculous because those two had market caps bellow 10b tesla has a market cap of 650b and is like the 7th largest company so people should really compare it to the large cap dot com names like cisco, Intel and yahoo.

author: Ironleg01
body:
There are still reasonably valued equities. Mostly your usual value names, some older tech companies and there are few currently hated companies. 
Value ones are some defence names like GD or RTX, I think they are still cheap, there are others too. Then old tech companies (but not necessarily bad ones) are HPE, JNPR, CSCO and few others. Finally hated names (I love buying hated but good companies for cheap) are INTC, GM and few others. There are some special situations too (like VRSK still hasn't fully recovered) and internationally there are interesting equities as well priced cheap. Popular names are expensive but they are popular so... But if you look outside of what people talk about on Reddit you can find some value.

author: zentraderx
body:
The tulip craze was about people ~~wanting~~ longing something. They went full FOMO on flowers. There was once a [Cisco](https://finance.yahoo.com/news/heres-much-investing-1-000-125124063.html) craze too. But this ended. Crypto never ended. They never turned off the servers.

Yesterdays transaction volume was about 70$ billion just for BTC. A spec to the 2 trillion moved daily in the fiat system, but still not nothing. If you are a property developer and it costs you 50k to move certain securities from one country to another and 10k with crypto, why wouldn't you save 40k with some calculated risk? This is driving the revolution. These people don't want tulips, they want to reduce their transaction/processing costs.

Since I'm invested in anything I mad 30% with ETH last 12 month. And due to regulatory systems where I live, I paid 0% income tax (instead of 25%) on this asset. This is similar in other parts of the world, which adds interest in this asset class.

author: lattiboy
body:
Right? It’s like everything was actually trading on a somewhat individual basis (except EV and chip makers)! I was getting so sick of stocks herding together! If I wanted something that boring I’d buy a fuckin ETF.

I ended up 2% green, but that all happened at the closing bell. No idea what happens tomorrow, as my assumption about value tech (eBay, Cisco, etc) bumping up didn’t come to fruition. 

I still think we end quite green this week, but there is some big underlying money moving itself around. EV, chips, SPACs and super speculative tech all had big shifts today on no specific news.

author: Investing8675309

author: Sgt-Bullish
body:
I’m not disagreeing with that, but that sort of reasoning doesn’t justify buying Cisco in the first half of 2000, so it should necessarily justify buying Palantir and Tesla now. 
They most likely have a future, but I can’t justify paying for a market cap that exceeds the some of the rest of the auto industry for Tesla when the only reason it posts a profit is because it sells off carbon taxes. It just looks to much like Cisco during the dotcom boom.

author: Lt_486

author: well-lighted
body: You can always go DIA if you're concerned about going too deep in tech. I think the Dow only includes AAPL, MSFT, CSCO, IBM, and INTC in the tech sector, which are all solid blue chips regardless of sector.

author: rally4cancer
body:
I mean my first response would be, what moment did BB get under Obama? The share price peaked before Obama was President, never recovered, and was trading at current prices when he left? Unless you believe Biden for some reason has some raging hard-on for BB that doesn't breach any conflict of interest or doesn't damage his reputation, I can't see why a Biden administration would favour BB massively. I also don't really see how BB would have friends in high places - where? John Chen's only been CEO since 2013, so for half the Obama presidency (and after BBs peak relevancy). And how would those friends in high places be any different to the friends any powerful CEO would have? I imagine Bill Gates/Satya Nadella and the rest of Microsoft could sway the US government far more effectively.

I know Obama used to use a BB phone, but he switched during his presidency, and I can't find what phone Biden uses. Additionally BB doesn't really make phones anymore so I can't see how it'd be too helpful. Might benefit TCL if the licensed BB phones are still in use. So I don't think there's even a serious reputational bonus for BB in the US government.

I mean obviously it's pure speculation talking about FB/Google etc, but until we start seeing serious repercussions for data leaks does it really matter? The whole cambridge analytica scandal cost FB $5bn, nothing. Data leak the other day affected over 500mn people and there's not much talk of serious repercussions. They can get grilled all they want they won't stop until there is serious consequences, and tbh I don't see Biden delivering that.

Talking of SolarWinds - you know the US government hasn't even announced they'll stop using SolarWinds, let alone the myriad of other suppliers like VMware, Cisco, Crowdstrike, Microsoft, GrammaTech, etc etc? I'd stake a bet that BB might be able to take advantage in a small way and get some more security contracts, but until I see that the US government is seriously thinking of shifting its cybersecurity outsourcing to BB I'm not going to believe it.

author: nessus42
body:
Remembering that your mouse was hovering over the buy button for 600 shares of Amazon in 1997... but then you changed your mind.

But that's not as bad as calling up your mother during the dot com bubble to tell her that it's time to sell her Cisco stock that you told her to buy in 1991 and cash in on her $43 million in gains, only to find out that she'd sold it years ago without telling you.

author: RoaringRocketKat
body:
I have used AutoCAD in the 90s and it's still used in construction.

The world is larger than the US, in most countries the choice is between AutoCAD and some locally produced legacy CAD software like made by the catholic school network.

There isn't much room for expansion and the competition tries to get a slice of that.

They only have to look at Cisco for inspiration: training courses and certifications.

Cisco network devices used to be the standard choice and nowadays there are plenty well established competitors. Their firewalls were ditched because of a NSA backdoor and Fortinet is nowadays the popular choice. No one uses Cisco WiFi, don't choose a course on that.

If you wonder how Cisco is still relevant, it's because everyone is still using/recognizing their training courses and certifications.

The education solution isn't just a way to expand, it can be the most important thing for long term survival.

author: 12A1313IT
body: Look up Cisco. You think this is the first time a bubble like this has happened? Remember back when Internet was the future? Funny thing is how the Cisco bulls were absolutely right and the stock did nothing for 15 years

author: soccers
body:
>it's a cyclical not a stock

It's literally like a stock because the currency is linked to a real company with 60+ employees. They're partnered with the largest insurance company in the world, Cisco is utilizing their framework, and the CEO has been on Joe Rogan and Lex Fridman. 

It's a basically a stake in the company and if the company does well and succeeds, then the price will go up.

author: Sgt-Bullish
body:
Cisco still hasn’t exceeded its height during the dotcom boom.

Just to be clear, what is under contention is whether tech is a good investment now, not whether it is ever a good investment. Tesla has a future, but do I think that future tracks a P/E of 1200 and a PEG of 120? No, and I imagine no one who actually values fundamental analysis does either.

author: WoodpeckerAlarmed239
body:
Thats a good point about the internet. It was so overvalued and everything came crashing down in march 2000. But some of those names are still around and are big worldwide operations. 

I own CSCO which was one of, if not, the biggest companies back in 2000 at a peak price of $80...21 years later it is at $53. But if you got in after the pop, in 2002 you could have gotten in at less than $10 and have made a 500% profit over the last 19 years. 

Down 34% over 21 years or up 500% over 19 years. Timing is everything.

author: rally4cancer
body:
BB and Cloudflare aren't comparable companies. They're both in cybersecurity but entirely different fields. Cloudflare deals with web infrastructure security, internet security, DDoS mitigation. BB is more IoT security, critical event management and UEM. They can't be comparably valued considered the products are vastly different.

A comparable company making security products in the same exact category (IoT, event management, UEM) is Cisco. Cisco trades at 4.67 P/S vs BBs 5.42 P/S. 

BB is also not a high-growth company comparable to Cloudflare which grows roughly 50%+ YoY, if you don't account for acquiring Cylance then BB revenue actually decreased in 2020 (again, like Cisco).

Blackberry QNX neutrino is a great product, and regarded a leader in autonomous vehicle OS, but it's **not** the only OS used by autonomous vehicle companies - most companies use several.

[https://www.intellias.com/everything-you-wanted-to-know-about-types-of-operating-systems-in-autonomous-vehicles/](https://www.intellias.com/everything-you-wanted-to-know-about-types-of-operating-systems-in-autonomous-vehicles/)

Not to mention the size of the market is tiny - globally the demand for AVs was 6700 units in 2020. 

[https://www.grandviewresearch.com/industry-analysis/autonomous-vehicles-market#:\~:text=The%20global%20autonomous%20vehicle%20market,innovation%20in%20the%20automotive%20industry](https://www.grandviewresearch.com/industry-analysis/autonomous-vehicles-market#:~:text=The%20global%20autonomous%20vehicle%20market,innovation%20in%20the%20automotive%20industry).

Predicting the size of the AV market is essentially impossible, but it's widely regarded that it won't take off significantly until at least 2030, and that's plenty of time for a other OS's to be developed, or for other companies to battle for market share. Hell VW itself is creating their own OS.

[https://www.grandviewresearch.com/industry-analysis/autonomous-vehicles-market#:\~:text=The%20global%20autonomous%20vehicle%20market,innovation%20in%20the%20automotive%20industry](https://www.grandviewresearch.com/industry-analysis/autonomous-vehicles-market#:~:text=The%20global%20autonomous%20vehicle%20market,innovation%20in%20the%20automotive%20industry).

BB has the **potential** to be a strong security player, but until it starts building out products in other areas like cloud security and web security, or showing off incredible growth figures, it's not going to be valued like Cloudflare, it'll sit at more comfortable valuations. Don't forget its still double what the price was at in April 2020.

author: programmingguy
body: Well, last year was an anomoly for some of my buys. I have a few new buys from last year or slightly earlier  that have became multibaggers....these companies have good stories, good growth but they are priced many multiples of current revenue, have little or no net income (but they nice operating margins and operating income so the reason they don't have net income is because profits go back into the business for reinvestment or marketing to increase market share) and they have to keep growing in the double digits to meet lofty expectations of growth. Any slight upset and the share price can tank and if there's a macro event that affects their business, it could have a similar response to the Dotcom bubble bursting IMHO. Dotcom blue chip darlings like Cisco, Microsoft, EMC were priced similarly (though they had netincome) but the multiples were crushed after the dotcom bubble burst. It took Microsoft some 10+ years & starting a dividend to get back to it's 2000 high, EMC never did and neither did Cisco after all these years.

author: notapersonaltrainer
body:
Of course it has value. Networks are consistently the most valuable entities on earth (ie FAANG). 

The most valuable network in the world is the [TCP/IP](https://www.cnet.com/news/how-much-is-the-internet-of-everything-worth-cisco-says-19-trillion/) network, ie the internet. There's just no scarce share or token of it that you can own. 

If it had native money built in, let's say 21,000,000 native undebasable tokens created from devoted & verifiable network computation that could be secured, synchronized and transferred across the entire internet and never double spent (let's call it "TCP/MP"), those tokens would potentially be worth millions today because of the utility, scarcity, and reach (and other monetary [properties](https://imgur.com/a/chbFIp5)). 

The Bitcoin Protocol is TCP/MP. Paypal plugs into the TCP/IP network for data transfer and recently the Bitcoin network for value transfer.

author: RecommendationNo6304
body:
Good discussions are always welcome.

They do have a loyal customer base. I've known a couple photographers since the 80's who have only ever bought Macintosh. Trouble is in the PC market it's a winner take all, and they've never gotten anywhere close to displacing Microsoft & the PC. For most of modern history Microsoft has owned something like 90% of the OS marketshare.

It doesn't seem to me like the phone market is the same situation. At least not yet. Perhaps it is just slower developing into dominant players on account of more global players in tech than the 90's had, but we are looking at Samsung, Apple, Huawei, Xiaomi, Oppo, etc. Apple had just 21% in Q4 2020, according to Counterpoint - and that was the biggest marketshare of any. Hardly a monopoly.

Security is definitely important, but it's not always an economic factor. What a reasonable person might think "Yeah definitely I want a secure device" doesn't always translate into the best security-focused companies wins. Look at the Equifax debacle. Talk about complete failure at the most basic levels. That problem rolled off their back like water off a duck. People were outraged, it's quickly forgotten in the news churn. When it comes to spending money on security upgrades (and people training!) any IT manager on earth will tell you it tends to be the lowest possible priority, right above fixing that broken soap dispenser in the men's room.

Google's dominance (in my view) is the fact that their API's and enabling software have tentacles into so many of the world's web services. If you want a fascinating experiment *block all google owned domains/IPs from your PC's localhost file* and then surf around the web a while. See just how many websites and services break.

They own the #1 and #2 most visited websites in the world (Google and Youtube), and it isn't even close (22B visits in February). #3 (Facebook) had 3.75B. #4 Amazon had 3.25B. #5 Wikipedia had 3.08B. #6 Yahoo 1.83B.

The 4 largest websites that are not Google-owned barely make up 50% of the visits Google sees each month.

The trouble smart phones are going to run into, I think, **is the problem of state-sanctioned monopoly**. When Microsoft dominated the PC market, it was basically the US, Europe and Japan. Some semiconductors in Korea, if we're being generous. But basically all the heavy lifting of added-value was happening in the US (Intel, IBM, Microsoft, Cisco, Novell (deceased), Apple, Sun Microsystems, etc).

But now the game is worldwide. China, Korea, lots of other places have real production capabilities and smart phones have opened a new frontier to own an enabling technology. Nation-states aren't stupid, they don't want to be beholden to the guy across the pond for their critical infrastructure. So they start putting protectionism into place and guarding the home-grown flavors, because those are the companies they can directly influence.

We're seeing a lot of this with EV's too. I don't know how it ends. Apple could turn out to own the whole cell phone pile. But I think it's a very risk that Google isn't nearly as susceptible to. I see no way Baidu or Yandex ever finds it's way into competing in western markets for search dominance.

author: BoyW1thADragonTattoo
body: It seriously depends on the company and the sector. Some companies are reliant on investor money to fuel their expansion or are for other reasons unsustainable post-bubble. Renewables are particularly bad for having companies with sub-par financial statements but sky high valuations. If their valuations pop, some of them will not survive. Beyond this, there are many healthy companies like (like Cisco) will not achieve boom era heights for decades. In essence, you'll be paying catch up rather than making money.

author: dr3amboy3657
body:
Cramer said it once on taxes.  Don’t worry about not paying the taxes so much, the market might take care of that for you.  What that means is that say your stock is @100 and you sell now and pay 35% in taxes or hold it and the stock goes down to 70 anyway.  

Now, the example is too simple but that’s the concept.  I like what the other OP said to reset your cost basis every now and then so it becomes more manageable.  It has become a huge problem for me too.   I too have massive long LGTC >500k on a stock that I’m not sure I want to hold for the next 5 years just so I can sell ~100k a year to reduce taxes.

You say TODAY you want to hold MSFT for a long time but at some point, you will have to pay the taxes.  MSFT might not be around when you retire in 20-30 years.  Just because MSFT has been doing well for the last 5 years doesn’t mean it will do well the next 25.   What if you had massive capital gains in Yahoo, Enron, Xom, Cisco, juniper, ibm, or GME(lol)?   Some are long gone and some have became dead money for years.

author: pekas13
body: Elastic is a search company built on a free and open heritage. Anyone can use Elastic products and solutions to get started quickly and frictionlessly. Elastic offers three solutions for enterprise search, observability, and security, built on one technology stack that can be deployed anywhere. From finding documents to monitoring infrastructure to hunting for threats, Elastic makes data usable in real time and at scale. Thousands of organizations worldwide, including Cisco, eBay, Goldman Sachs, Microsoft, The Mayo Clinic, NASA, The New York Times, Wikipedia, and Verizon, use Elastic to power mission-critical systems. Founded in 2012, Elastic is a distributed company with Elasticians around the globe and is publicly traded on the NYSE under the symbol ESTC. Learn more at elastic.co.

author: Floofyboy
body:
Timing Microsoft's decline won't be as easy as you think. At some point their stock will start to fall, you will think its just randomness of the market as usual, but in reality there is a good reason and you will lose money.



Am i saying i think Microsoft specifically will be the first FANG to fall? no. I have no idea which FANG will fall, but i really think at least one of them will in the next 20 years. And timing the selling won't be as easy as you think.


Microsoft for example... maybe windows won't be as optimal with quantum computers and some other company will build a better OS for it.


FB already has tons of issues with anti trust laws and countries wanting to tax them.


Amazon is slowly getting more competitors.


my point is a lot of stuff can happen in 20 years. in 2000 nobody would have predicted how badly BB or Cisco fell.

author: MichaelBurryScott
body:
I see. If you wanted to close the spread, you can ask for slightly less than its intrinsic value just before expiration. For example, for your CSCO spread, you can try to close it for $12.45, $12.40 and keep lowering your ask until you’re comfortable with the return relative to pin risk. If you do that an hour or two before expiration, you’re likely getting a fill close to max profit, regardless of the bid/ask spread. You just have to give the MMs and HFTs enough of an edge to take the trade off your hands. 

When an option expires ITM it’s automatically exercised by the OCC, i.e. converted to shares. If you (or your broker on your behalf) sends a Do Not Exercise request for that call, it won’t be exercised and hence expires worthless. 

A year ago, there was this viral post here from a RH trader that had a deep ITM call on SHOP (or SPOT, I can’t remember). And they didn’t have enough money to exercise it. RH just let that call expire worthless and the trader lost on around $300K+ of profit.

author: Pietro405
body:
Thanks

Yogi Berra: try not to make predictions especially about the future !

Possible catalysts for a recovery in NOK stock. One is the NEW CEO announces some dividend in next 3 months and second the earnings in next Q exceeds his very gloomy outlook he presented few months ago at his first earnings call. This is a standard practice of new CE0s called UPOD ( under promise and over deliver and appear smart in front of the ANAL-ysts ); recent examples: GE,WFC and KHC turnarounds where stocks have gone up 80pct. There also exists the possibility that a Qualcomm or Csco could make a bid.

Also look at 7pct yielding LUMN and let me know what you think.

[https://money.usnews.com/investing/stock-market-news/slideshows/stocks-michael-burry-likes-better-than-tesla](https://money.usnews.com/investing/stock-market-news/slideshows/stocks-michael-burry-likes-better-than-tesla)

author: lxc1227
body:
The start-up granted him stock options worth $1.5 millions (a lot of the money at the time and the company was not even publicly traded).  At the time of acquisition by Cisco, he opted to take $1.5 millions of Cisco stocks (instead of $1.5M cash).  IRS treated the exercise as taxable income and he paid income taxes on full $1.5 millions.

Shortly after, dot-com bubbled and Cisco stocks dropped to 10% of the previous value.  His $1.5M stocks turned into $150K.

The $1.35M stock losses can't offset against his $1.5M option gain.

author: teslas_love_pigeon
body:
Why is a Nokia a solid play? They are competing with Dell, Cisco, Ericsson, Verizon, Samsung, Huawei; even other companies you wouldn't think about telecommunications have their own hardware as well such as Facebook and Google.

Nokia also has a massive amount of fucking shares. They need extremely large movements in order to raise the stock price. Movements like being the first to market in 6g (or whatever the fucked up name is for the next iteration) not being a mid player in a oversaturated market..

As for BB (and I say this as a recently dumped bagholder, still have my Jan 2023 15C leaps), they have done nothing to proven they know how to pivot to a SaaS company. You mention cybersecurity... every company is selling cybersecurity services for IoT. Go on the AWS market place and you can choose from hundreds of SMEs as consultants:

https://aws.amazon.com/security/partner-solutions/?partner-solutions-cards.sort-by=item.additionalFields.partnerNameLower&partner-solutions-cards.sort-order=asc&awsf.partner-solutions-filter-partner-type=*all&awsf.Filter%20Name%3A%20partner-solutions-filter-partner-categories=*all&awsf.partner-solutions-filter-partner-location=*all#Consulting_Partners

don't want services, what about products?

https://aws.amazon.com/marketplace/solutions/security

Literally click any box and you'll see dozens of services overall.

Just because BB put up a shite product on the AWS Marketplace doesn't mean much, I can do the same thing after paying some fees as well. It's equivalent to the app store.

This is also just one ecosystem, Google, IBM, Microsoft, Oracle, etc all have equivalents.

What about direct companies? Companies like CrowdStrike, Palo Alto Networks, CyberArk, Zscaler, FireEye, Proofpoint.

BB is terrible about productization. There's a reason why talent is flocking to companies like Amazon, Google, Facebook, Salesforce, Oracle, Netflix, etc; because BB is a dead-end.

They have to do a lot, they don't need a management shakeup; they need a shakeup in their board and executive team. I don't see that happening, so unless they give their management the go-ahead to make and experience many possible sources of revenue they will continue to falter behind.

author: justjared725
body:
Yeah + $40k of equipment.  But the real story was the correction statement: "Not included in the 2020 Q1 financials are the previously referenced Bitcoin buys of 513 BTC (circa 2014) and the conflicting 576 BTC (circa 2016) as seen and carried over from previous managements reports. As of Q1 2020 current management has yet to receive any company (CCTL) books, statements, bank info, property, assets or proof of any Bitcon holdings from old management. All previous financial reports 2018 and 2019 were mostly reconstructed from previous reports filed by Coin Citadel and old CEO Bill Schaefer. Without substantive proof of current Bitcoin holdings still held by old management, or that a loss was incurred from an unusual event and or negligent action by prior management due to lost access to private keys and or wallets, or Bitcoin was sold and previous sale was never disclosed to new management, Coin Citadel cannot continue to reference the aforementioned Bitcoin Treasury in its financials moving forward."

So it's either been a scam or someone pocketed 500+ bitcoin, or someone lost access to wallets. NO ONE JUST MISPLACES THE KEYS TO $30m OF BITCOIN.

author: TCB47
body:
Vanguard has some very good funds available in the US & I would assume they have something similar in the UK.  My wife & I have our primary investments housed with Fidelity Investment here in the U.S. and they are all in a diversified retirement account.

Current distribution is 40/60 with 40% in bond & 60% stock mutuals.  We are retirement age hence the heavier allocation to bonds.  You could get by with a heavier stock weighting.

Our stocks are split among growth funds, medical, technology and communications.  The keys for us have been to not panic and let things ride during some of the downturns.  I do rebalance the account at the first of the year to try to keep the bond/stock split close to my desired weighting.

With retirement funds, I have stayed away from straight stock ownership and for us, that has worked very well.  It's amazing what the compounding will accomplish by allowing the funds to reinvest the dividends and capital gains back info the funds.  Good luck.

BTW, I am using Robinhood to "play" with options with some disposable, not going to miss it, funds.  I just won't get wild with the retirement account.

author: dont-YOLO-ragequit
body:
This really lack any due Diligence. 
Are you just trolling to get the answers fed to you or did you just poorly formulated a Change my view post? 

Doesn't reay matter who invented it as the basis of it has been optimized by the competition between all crypto currencies. In other words the un verified unsecured currencies died a decade plus ago from not being hack proof.

The currencies are currently competing with each other the same way the Yen, Euro, US dollar and more are competing with each other. They all have their own supply and demand and the more credible companies hop on, the more credible it will get.(compared to currencies being manipulated by stimulus packages, interest rates and buying other currencies). 


It IS being regulated and audited. The mid February crash happened because some firm falsely stated that they found a double transaction. It was later backtracked but the damage was done. 

The values is linked to how hard it is to mine 1 coin at this point. You could mine a coin with an idle computer so at the time it was chump change, now it takes high powered hardware, a heavy electricity bill and a ton of cooling to get one so the price goes along with it + how it can only get harder to have one. 

Your coins are as secure as you make it. There are crypted USB keys  to keep your wallet safe but like everything, the more valuable it is, the more someone will have the patience to get it.

The future is in that it cuts currency exchange fees(the banks) and rates(the government) and financial institutions from host to client. You get a coin, you trade parts of it the way you want internationally or confidentially with no brick and mortar fees. 

The GME saga showed big banks can and will interfere to make money over the well being of free market.

Bitcoin might not be the end all solution but something can be said about the infrastructure behind it where no "package"(hash) can be hacked since the time and date , the number of characters, sender and receivers , and so much of the the data that makes the hash can be used to encrypt it thus can't be "reinserted" in the blockchain.
